title: Putting customers first is 'not easy': AMP
text:
He said “getting money back to clients” who have been aggrieved, and fixing “legacy” issues through product development is his top priority in rebuilding trust “one client at a time”.

Offering what he said is an “outside-in” take on Australia’s wealth management landscape, the US-born Italian and Swiss citizen said the industry, including AMP, has historically been too focused on financial product distribution, as opposed to what he called “holistic advice”.

“Australia hasn’t really seen a true wealth industry,” he said. “Everyone has just been focused on selling products.”

AMP’s prioritisation of product sales over client outcomes came under fire at the Hayne royal commission, including evidence provided during former executive Jack Regan’s testimony that the company’s Buyer of Last Resort scheme for its financial advisory network relied on a calculated that favoured in-house AMP products.

Ending fragmentation

Mr De Ferrari said the financial services industry suffered from isolation between the various segments such as banking, financial advice and superannuation.

“The value chain is completely fragmented and each part of the chain is trying to protect its profits,” he said.

He revealed that ending that fragmentation was a chief motivation for the company’s recent decision to combine its wealth management and banking businesses into a single internal organisation and under the single leadership of his former Credit Suisse colleague, Alex Wade.

“If you build a business around clients you need to go to the core of client needs,” he said, adding that consideration of a client’s superannuation without being able to provide advice on mortgages and home ownership does not allow for “holistic advice”.

He also indicated that he sees the mortgage lending business as a substantial contributor to the company’s survival prospects.

“We have a bank that no-one talks about that delivers exceptional value,” he said.

However, some analysts and critics have noted that the merger of banking and wealth management into a single unit creates a more vertically integrated business, with greater potential for conflicts of interest, as concluded by the Hayne royal commission.

‘Episodic advice’

Although analysts have viewed the decision to combine banking and wealth as a move towards Credit Suisse-style private banking, Mr De Ferrari made clear he sees AMP as remaining a provider of services to mainstream consumers, referring often to a hypothetical investor “earning an average of $80,000 per year”.

He suggested that “episodic” or “modular” advice, whereby consumers would receive financial advice on an irregular basis at certain key life stages, may become an important part of the company’s future, admitting that face to face advice has become “very expensive”.

He said the current regulatory approach to financial product advice being considered either personal or general advice is too restrictive, and that there is “room for something in between”.

“I don’t think any government has really cracked this issue [of digital advice and providing quality financial advice to low balance customers],” Mr De Ferrari said, vowing to work with regulators to find ways to provide this “episodic” advice in a compliant way.

‘Glass half full’

In laying out what he said was a “passionate” commitment to Australian wealth management, Mr De Ferrari also mildly criticised the big four banks, who are in varying stages of divestment from wealth management.

“When you have complexity on the client side...and complexity from a business perspective it is not surprising that a lot of players are running for the door,” he said.

The exit of these unnamed players from wealth management due to rising complexity and regulatory scrutiny is leaving a significant “unmet advice need”, Mr De Ferrari criticised.

“But I am a glass half-full guy,” he said. “In disruption there is opportunity.”
description: AMP chief executive Francesco De Ferrari has conceded that 'pivoting a business towards clients is an interesting drive that I am pushing very hard.
